source.name: City of Houston Solid Waste Management Department
source.notes: Based on official City of Houston Solid Waste Management recycling guidelines. Houston uses a single green recycling cart with bi-weekly collection. No curbside composting program.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: Houston accepts plastics #1-#5 and #7
Collected bi-weekly on the same day as garbage
commonMistakes: Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags; items must be loose
Don't include bottles with liquid still inside

materials.name: Plastic jugs
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: HDPE #2 jugs are among the most valuable recyclables
Bi-weekly collection
commonMistakes: Don't crush; leave intact with cap on

materials.name: Plastic tubs and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: Must be labeled #1-#5 or #7
No styrofoam containers
commonMistakes: Don't include black plastic takeout containers
No styrofoam or foam trays

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
Bi-weekly collection
commonMistakes: Don't crush; leave whole
Don't bag; place loose in cart

materials.name: Tin / steel cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: Both tin and steel cans accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Glass bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: Houston accepts glass curbside, unlike some Texas cities
All colors of glass accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap and trash it
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics

materials.name: Glass jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Lids can stay on
Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: All food-grade glass jars accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include heat-treated glass (Pyrex, ovenware)
Don't include ceramics

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Place loose in green recycling cart
Do not bag
notes: One of the most efficiently recycled materials
commonMistakes: Don't bag newspapers in plastic bags
Don't include if heavily soiled or wet

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Place loose in green recycling cart
Staples and binding are okay
notes: Glossy paper is accepted in Houston recycling
commonMistakes: Don't bag; place loose

materials.name: Office paper
instructions: Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: Clean dry paper is one of the most recyclable materials
commonMistakes: Don't include shredded paper; Houston does NOT accept shredded paper in recycling

materials.name: Junk mail and envelopes
instructions: Place loose in green recycling cart
Window envelopes are okay; no need to remove plastic window
notes: All clean dry mail is accepted
commonMistakes: Don't bag mail

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Flatten completely
Remove all packing materials (bubble wrap, foam, air pillows)
Maximum 3x3 feet; cut down larger boxes
Place in or beside green recycling cart
notes: Must be flattened and no larger than 3x3 feet
Bi-weekly collection with recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease or food
Don't leave packing materials inside
Must be flattened

materials.name: Cereal and food boxes
instructions: Flatten
Remove plastic liner (trash it)
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Thin paperboard / chipboard is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove plastic liner bags

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if present
Place loose in green recycling cart
notes: Both gable-top (milk) and aseptic (juice box) cartons accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten cartons

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Place in original container with cap secured, OR pour into a clean 1-gallon milk or water jug
Set container beside (not inside) the green recycling cart on collection day
notes: Houston uniquely allows motor oil to be placed beside the recycling cart for curbside pickup
Maximum 1 gallon per collection
This is a special Houston program; most cities require drop-off
commonMistakes: Don't pour motor oil down any drain
Don't mix with other fluids
Don't put inside the recycling cart; set it beside the cart
Limit 1 gallon per collection
examples: Used engine oil in original bottle
Motor oil in a milk jug

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up into a fist-sized ball
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with food baked on

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in green recycling cart
notes: Only empty aerosol cans are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized or has contents
Don't puncture cans

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in green recycling cart
notes: Clean paper bags are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include bags soiled with food or grease

materials.name: Phone books
instructions: Place in green recycling cart
notes: Accepted as-is
commonMistakes: Don't bag

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition to Houston Public Library, Goodwill, or Half Price Books
If damaged, remove hardcover and place paper pages in green recycling cart
Trash non-paper covers and bindings
notes: Donating is always preferable to recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in trash
Houston does NOT accept shredded paper in recycling
notes: Shredded paper clogs recycling machinery and is too small to sort
For secure document destruction, use a commercial shredding service
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Plastic bags and film
instructions: Do NOT put in green recycling cart
Take to H-E-B, Kroger, Walmart, or Target for store drop-off recycling
Otherwise place in trash
notes: Plastic bags jam Houston's recycling machinery
Many Houston-area grocery stores accept bags for recycling
commonMistakes: Never put recyclables inside a plastic bag; items must be loose
Never put any film plastic in the green cart

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene
instructions: Place in trash
Not accepted in Houston recycling
notes: Styrofoam (#6 polystyrene) is not recyclable in Houston's program
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Plastic #6
instructions: Place in trash
#6 plastic is not accepted in Houston recycling
notes: Houston only accepts plastics #1-#5 and #7
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling cart

materials.name: Food waste
instructions: Place in trash
Houston does NOT have curbside composting
notes: Unlike Austin and some other Texas cities, Houston has no citywide composting program
Food waste goes in your regular trash cart
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the green recycling cart; the green cart is for recycling only

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
instructions: Place in trash
No curbside composting in Houston
notes: Houston does not have a residential composting program
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in trash
No curbside composting in Houston
notes: Houston has no residential composting program
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in trash
Wrap to contain odors if desired
notes: No composting program in Houston
Meat is never accepted in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling cart

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Pour expired liquids down drain
Solid dairy waste goes in trash
Rinse and recycle the container separately
notes: No composting in Houston
commonMistakes: Don't pour grease down the drain

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: Place in trash
No composting in Houston
notes: Houston has no curbside composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling cart

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Place in trash
No curbside composting in Houston
notes: Consider home composting if desired
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling cart

materials.name: Eggs and eggshells
instructions: Place in trash
notes: No curbside composting in Houston
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling cart

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Greasy/food-soiled pizza boxes go in trash
Clean portions (lid) can be torn off and recycled in green cart
notes: Food-soiled cardboard contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put grease-soaked cardboard in recycling

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
instructions: Place in trash
Food-soiled paper cannot be recycled
notes: Houston has no composting program for food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Plastic-lined paper cups go in trash
Plastic lids: green recycling cart (if #1-#5 or #7)
Paper sleeves: green recycling cart
notes: The plastic lining prevents paper cup recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in recycling

materials.name: Candy wrappers
instructions: Place in trash
Metallized plastic film is not recyclable
notes: Candy wrappers appear metallic but are not aluminum; they are laminated plastic
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Chip bags and snack pouches
instructions: Place in trash
Metallized film is not recyclable
notes: The shiny interior is aluminum bonded to plastic; not separable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Place in trash
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Receipts
instructions: Place in trash
Thermal paper contains BPA and cannot be recycled
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling cart

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Pet waste contains harmful bacteria
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash
Wax coating prevents recycling
notes: No composting available in Houston for wax paper
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling cart

materials.name: Bubble wrap and packing materials
instructions: Place in trash
Or drop off plastic film at grocery store collection bins
notes: Plastic film jams recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling cart
Remove from cardboard boxes before recycling the boxes

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in trash
Mixed plastic; not recyclable
notes: Some brands like TerraCycle offer mail-back programs
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Makeup and cosmetics containers
instructions: Most cosmetic containers go in trash due to mixed materials and small size
Large, clean #1/#2/#5 containers can go in recycling
notes: Small items fall through sorting screens at the recycling facility
commonMistakes: Don't put tiny containers in recycling

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT put in trash or recycling
Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling facilities
Houston has multiple Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Centers that accept batteries for free
commonMistakes: Never put batteries in the green recycling cart
Never put batteries in trash

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Best Buy also accepts many electronics for free recycling
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: Houston has Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Centers in multiple locations
Texas law discourages e-waste in landfills
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or recycling cart
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Smartphone / cell phone
instructions: Factory reset and remove SIM card first
Trade in at carrier stores or Apple/Samsung
Take to Best Buy or Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
notes: Many Houston carrier stores offer trade-in credit
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data
Don't throw in trash

materials.name: Chargers, cables, cords
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center or Best Buy
Do NOT put in green recycling cart
notes: Cords, hoses, wires, and cables tangle in recycling machinery and are specifically banned from Houston curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Never put cables, cords, or wires in the recycling cart; they shut down sorting equipment

materials.name: Hoses and wires
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Do NOT place in trash or recycling carts
notes: Houston specifically prohibits hoses, wires, and cords in recycling; they wrap around sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Never put in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Latex paint: can also dry it out completely with kitty litter or newspaper and trash the solid
Oil-based paint: must go to hazardous waste drop-off
notes: Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Centers accept household hazardous waste for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down any drain
Don't put liquid paint in trash

materials.name: Pesticides and household chemicals
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Keep in original labeled containers
Never mix chemicals
notes: Houston accepts household hazardous waste at Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Centers for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains
Don't put in trash
Don't mix different chemicals

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Never put in trash or recycling
notes: Pressurized containers are fire and explosion risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in recycling or trash

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a Houston-area pharmacy drug take-back program
Houston Police Department substations may host periodic take-back events
If no drop-off available: mix with coffee grounds or kitty litter, seal in a container, and trash
notes: Never flush medications
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center (contains mercury)
LED bulbs: e-waste drop-off
Incandescent: wrap and place in trash
notes: Home Depot and Lowe's locations in Houston accept CFL bulbs
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in trash; they contain mercury

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Handle carefully; contains mercury
notes: Many Houston-area hardware stores also accept fluorescent tubes
commonMistakes: Don't break them
Don't put in trash

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Some Houston restaurants accept used cooking oil
notes: Never pour grease down the drain; it causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains
Small amounts can be absorbed with paper towel and trashed

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Most tire retailers accept old tires when you buy new ones
notes: Up to 10 tires accepted per visit at Depository Centers
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or Houston-area thrift stores
Textile recycling bins available at various Houston locations
Do NOT place in green recycling cart
notes: Houston specifically lists clothing as not accepted in recycling
Even worn-out textiles can go in textile recycling bins
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the green recycling cart
Don't trash wearable clothing; donate it

materials.name: Yard waste and tree waste
instructions: Place in a separate pile at curb for tree waste collection
Call Houston 311 to schedule pickup if needed
Keep separated from trash and recycling
Branches should be cut to 4 feet or shorter and bundled
notes: Houston provides separate tree waste/yard waste collection; call 311
Yard waste does NOT go in the green recycling cart or the trash cart
Schedule and frequency vary by area
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in the green recycling cart
Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't mix with regular trash

materials.name: Furniture and large items
instructions: Schedule a junk waste / heavy trash pickup through Houston 311
Place at curb on scheduled heavy trash day
Or take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
notes: Houston has monthly heavy trash collection days that vary by neighborhood
Check your collection schedule at houstontx.gov or call 311
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb outside of heavy trash day
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule heavy trash pickup through Houston 311
Place at curb on scheduled heavy trash day
Or take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
notes: Heavy trash days vary by neighborhood
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb outside of heavy trash day

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Label as BROKEN GLASS
Place in trash
notes: Metallic coating prevents glass recycling
commonMistakes: Never put mirrors in the green recycling cart

materials.name: Ceramics and dishware
instructions: Place in trash
Ceramics are not recyclable
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling cart with glass

materials.name: Ink and toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot
Manufacturer mail-back programs available
Best Buy also accepts cartridges
notes: Many stores offer credit for returned cartridges
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash

materials.name: Car battery
instructions: Take to AutoZone, O'Reilly, or any auto parts store
Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Centers also accept them
Most stores will take old batteries when you buy a new one
notes: Lead-acid batteries are almost 100% recyclable
commonMistakes: Never put in trash or curbside recycling
Handle carefully; contains acid

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Place in a rigid, puncture-resistant container (like a laundry detergent bottle)
Seal container when full
Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
notes: Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
commonMistakes: Never put in recycling
Never put loose in trash

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Food-soiled wrappers: trash
Clean paper wrappers: green recycling cart if they are clean dry paper
notes: No composting program in Houston for food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in recycling

materials.name: Plastic straws and utensils
instructions: Place in trash
Too small and lightweight to be sorted at recycling facility
notes: Small plastics fall through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Wire hangers: take to a dry cleaner for reuse, or trash
Plastic hangers: trash
Do not place in green recycling cart
notes: Wire hangers tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put any hangers in recycling

materials.name: Small appliances
instructions: Take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Or schedule heavy trash pickup through 311 for larger items
notes: Many small appliances contain recyclable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling cart

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Schedule heavy trash pickup through Houston 311
Or take to a Houston Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
Some retailers offer haul-away when delivering new appliances
notes: Large appliances (white goods) contain recyclable metals and must be handled separately
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Bagged recyclables
instructions: Do NOT bag your recyclables
Workers will not open bags; bagged items go straight to landfill
Empty bag contents loose into the green recycling cart
notes: Houston requires all recyclables to be placed LOOSE in the cart; never in bags
This is one of the most common recycling mistakes in Houston
commonMistakes: Never put recyclables in a plastic bag
Never put recyclables in a trash bag

recycle: Plastic bottles, jugs, tubs, and jars (#1-#5 and #7, empty and rinsed)
Aluminum and tin/steel cans (empty and rinsed)
Glass bottles and jars (empty and rinsed)
Newspapers, magazines, catalogs, office paper, junk mail
Milk, juice, and broth cartons (empty and rinsed)
Motor oil (in container, placed beside cart, max 1 gallon)
trash: ALL food waste (no curbside composting in Houston)
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

tips: Houston uses a GREEN cart for recycling (not blue)
Collection is BI-WEEKLY on the same day as garbage
All items must be LOOSE in the cart; never bag recyclables
Motor oil can go BESIDE the green cart (max 1 gallon, in sealed container)
No curbside composting; all food waste goes in trash
Glass IS accepted curbside in Houston
Yard waste / tree waste: call 311 for separate pickup
Hazardous waste, e-waste, and tires: take to Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Centers

locations.name: North Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
locations.notes: Free for Houston residents with valid ID. Closed Sundays and Mondays.

locations.name: South Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
locations.notes: Free for Houston residents with valid ID. Closed Sundays and Mondays.

locations.name: Southwest Neighborhood Depository/Recycling Center
locations.notes: Free for Houston residents with valid ID. Closed Sundays and Mondays.

locations.name: Westpark Recycling Center
locations.notes: Free for Houston residents with valid ID. Closed Sundays and Mondays.
